newsitem.title: USA: U.S. meat exports up 6 pct in Jan-July -- USDA.
newsitem.headline: U.S. meat exports up 6 pct in Jan-July -- USDA.

text.p: U.S. 1996 meat and meat product exports reached $4.985 billion in January-to-July period, up six percent from the same time last year, said Agriculture Department.
By the end of the year, the total is expected to exceed the record $8.383 billion registered for 1995, USDA said in its Livestock and Poultry world report.
January-July U.S. pork exports are 40 percent ahead of last year at 655 million, and poultry exports were up 23 percent at $1.301 billion.
The scare over mad cow disease in Britain and the E. Coli outbreak in Japan were responsible, in part, for increasing white meat exports, the report said.
In the seven months, there was a 19-percent drop in the value of bovine hides and skins exports to $715 million and a 24-percent drop in tallow and grease exports to $338 million.
Variety meat exports rose 15 percent to $446 million, mainly due to a 29-percent increase in exports to Japan.
Pork and variety meat exports to Russia were down 50 percent and 32 percent, respectively, because of higher prices, but poultry exports to Russia were up 57 percent.
Pork exports to Japan climbed 64 percent in January to July, as importers rushed to bring in pork in anticipation of Japan's "safeguard mechanism," which guards against import surges.
